div.ab: For sowing melons well, one needs it to be the end of a moon cycle for otherwise they would bud too many leaves & not bear enough fruit. Make small e holes, two fingers by two fingers, with a pickaxe & put in each two or three seeds. Next, take very fine earth & fill the depressions lightly with it. Next, spread over all to the thickness of a thumb havets, that is to say wheat fl chaff, in order that the coming rain does not beat the earth & prevent their birth. Havets attract field mice who eat the seeds. And for avoiding this, one must moisten them with s a decoction of wormwood.

Some do not saturate the glass with gris d'escaille for working as primer, but trace on the clean glass with noir à huile. But it is very necessary that the wood be rid of grease, because if it has even a bit of grease, the color will not take on it at all. And further, if the glassworker who is working has a stench from his nose or his mouth la, & he breathes on the glass, the color will not take on it. Those who discovered the invention of working in small works of supple enamels use only esmail d'azur, which is blue, & esmail colombin, which is the color of purple, which they make supple with rock pieces or leaded glass. As for the yellow, they make it from silver, the red from sanguine, as is said elsewhere, the black & gray & shadows with the noir d'escaille, either strong or weak, the carnation with the light sanguine. The green is made first from yellow, then on top they coat esmail d'azur, either strong or weak, according to whether they want to make it bright or dark.

It is cut with a file, then one passes a certain pulverized salt across the surface, which an Englishman called desramonet. But I believe that this was pulverized pumice stone, for it had the harshness of arène. And with a taut cord, he polished his amber, then passed tripoli from Bretagne on it with the finger; others used a piece of leather or a cane. Amber loses its color if an unhealthy person wears it, & becomes whitish. But to restore it, it needs to be soaked for one night in urine, then boiled a little in it.
